title: How to Find the Force of Gravity in Physics

steps.title: The equation to find the source of gravity is F g r a v = ( G m 1 m 2 ) / d {\displaystyle Fgrav=(Gm1m2)/d} .
steps.content: The equation to find the source of gravity is F g r a v = ( G m 1 m 2 ) / d {\displaystyle Fgrav=(Gm1m2)/d} . When determining the force of gravity between two objects, use the equation F g r a v = ( G m 1 m 2 ) / d {\displaystyle Fgrav=(Gm1m2)/d} . [1] X Research source This equation takes into account the masses of both objects and how far apart the objects are from each other. The variables are defined below: [2] X Research source Fgrav is the force due to gravity, measured in Newtons (N) G is the universal gravitation constant 6.673 x 10 Nm/kg m1 is the mass of the first object m2 is the mass of the second object d is the distance between the centers of two objects Sometimes you will see the letter r used instead of the letter d . Both symbols represent the distance between the two objects.

steps.title: Determine the variables of the equation.
steps.content: Determine the variables of the equation. Depending on the problem, you may be given all but one or two variables. Plug the given variables into your equation and notice what you’re attempting to solve or find. Here’s a refresher of the gravitational force equation and its variables: [3] X Research source Equation: F g r a v = ( G m 1 m 2 ) / d {\displaystyle Fgrav=(Gm1m2)/d} Fgrav is the force due to gravity, measured in Newtons (N) G is the universal gravitation constant 6.673 x 10 Nm/kg m1 is the mass of the first object m2 is the mass of the second object d * or r*** is the distance between the centers of two objects

steps.title: Use metric units for each variable in the equation.
steps.content: Use metric units for each variable in the equation. For this particular equation, you must use metric units. The masses of objects need to be in kilograms (kg), and the distances need to be in meters (m). If your variables are not already in metric units, convert them before solving the equation. Stuck on how to convert your measurements? Try using a conversion calculator online.

steps.title: Determine the mass of the object in question.
steps.content: Determine the mass of the object in question. If you’re not given the masses of the objects for the equation within a problem, you may need to find them yourself. For smaller objects, you can weigh them on a scale or balance to determine their weight in grams. For larger objects, you may have to look up the approximate mass online. But, most likely, the mass of the objects will be provided to you. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Measure the distance between the two objects.
steps.content: Measure the distance between the two objects. For some problems, you may be asked to do some extra math to reveal the distance between the two objects. The most common example of this is a problem calculating the force of gravity between an object and Earth. In this example, you would need to determine how far away the object is from the center of the Earth. [5] X Research source The distance from the surface of the Earth to the center is approximately 6.38 x 10 m. You can find resources online with approximate distances from the center of the Earth to objects at various elevations on the surface—just do a quick online search if the information isn’t provided.

steps.title: Plug your variables into the equation to solve.
steps.content: Plug your variables into the equation to solve. Once you have defined the variables of your equation, you can work on solving the equation. Use the proper order of operations , and be sure that all of your units are in metric units. [6] X Research source Here’s an example problem: The problem: Determine the force of gravity on a 68 kg person on the surface of the Earth. The mass of the Earth is 5.98 x 10 kg. Make sure all your variables have the proper units. m1 = 5.98 x 10 kg, m2 = 68 kg, G = 6.673 x 10 Nm/kg, and d = 6.38 x 10 m Write your equation: F g r a v = ( G m 1 m 2 ) / d ″ = [ ( 6.67 x 10 ) x 68 x ( 5.98 x 10 ) ] / ( 6.38 x 10 ) {\displaystyle Fgrav=(Gm1m2)/d''=[(6.67x10)x68x(5.98x10)]/(6.38x10)} Multiply the masses of the two objects together. 68 x (5.98 x 10) = 4.06 x 10 Multiply the product of m1 and m2 by the gravitational constant G . (4.06 x 10) x (6.67 x 10) = 2.708 x 10 Square the distance between the two objects. (6.38 x 10) = 4.07 x 10 Divide the product of G x m1 x m2 by the distance squared to find the force of gravity in Newtons (N). 2.708 x 10/4.07 x 10 = 665 N The answer: The force of gravity is 665 N.

steps.title: Use the equation F g r a v = m g {\displaystyle Fgrav=mg} to calculate an estimated force of gravity.
steps.content: Use the equation F g r a v = m g {\displaystyle Fgrav=mg} to calculate an estimated force of gravity. As academic tutor Sean Alexander explains, on Earth, the force of gravity causes objects to accelerate at a rate of 9.8 m/s. If you’re calculating the gravitational force of an object on Earth, you can simplify the lengthy F g r a v = ( G M e a r t h m ) / d {\displaystyle Fgrav=(GMearthm)/d} to F g r a v = m g {\displaystyle Fgrav=mg} . [7] X Research source If you want a more exact approximation of force, you can still use the equation F g r a v = ( G M e a r t h m ) / d {\displaystyle Fgrav=(GMearthm)/d} . Be sure your variables are in metric units (kilograms and meters) before trying to solve.

steps.title: Solve the equation F g r a v = m g {\displaystyle Fgrav=mg} to determine the gravitational force on Earth.
steps.content: Solve the equation F g r a v = m g {\displaystyle Fgrav=mg} to determine the gravitational force on Earth. Once you have defined the variables of your equation, you can plug them in and solve. Be sure that all of your units are in metric, and you’re using the proper order of operations to solve. [8] X Research source Let’s use the same equation from above and see how close the approximation is: The problem: Determine the force of gravity on a 68 kg person on the surface of the earth. Convert the variables to the proper units: m = 68 kg, g = 9.8 m/s. Write the equation: Fgrav = mg = 68*9.8 = 666 N. The answer: With F = mg, the force of gravity is 666 N, while using the more exact equation yields a force of 665 N. As you can see, these values are almost identical.

steps.title: The formula for the Second Law of gravity is F = ma.
steps.content: The formula for the Second Law of gravity is F = ma . Newton’s Second Law of Motion states that any object will accelerate when acted upon by a net or unbalanced force. In other words, if a force is acting upon an object that’s greater than the forces acting in the opposite direction, the object will accelerate in the direction of the larger force. This law can be summed up with the equation F = ma , where F is the force, m is the mass of the object, and a is the acceleration. [9] X Research source Using this law, we can calculate the gravitational force of any object on the Earth's surface, given the known acceleration due to gravity.
How much force does it take to hold an apple with a mass of 0.1 kg on Earth? F = mg F = 0.1 x 9.8 F = 0.98 N [10] X Research source
A man hits a gold ball (0.2 kg), which accelerates at a rate of 20 m/s². What amount of force acted on the ball? F = ma F = 0.2 x 20 F = 4 N [11] X Research source

steps.title: Is 9.8 the force of gravity?
steps.content: Is 9.8 the force of gravity? Yes, the exact value of g , or the force of gravity, is 9.80665 m/s², which is usually rounded to 9.8 m/s². This is the average value of the gravitational force on Earth. [12] X Research source This number is typically used in most physics problems as the value of g , unless otherwise stated.

steps.title: What is Newton’s Law of Gravity?
steps.content: What is Newton’s Law of Gravity? Sir Isaac Newton’s Law of Gravity (also known as the Law of Universal Gravitation) states that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe, creating a proportional force. In other words, gravity is the reason objects fall or stay in place. [13] X Research source Fun facts: Heavier objects have a stronger force of gravity between them, and objects that are close to each other have more gravity between them.

steps.title: What is the constant force of gravity?
steps.content: What is the constant force of gravity? In the gravity equation, the constant force of gravity is represented by the variable G or g— the universal gravitational constant. [14] X Research source On Earth, the gravitational constant is 9.8 m/s². [15] X Research source

steps.title: What is the gravitational force between the Earth and the Moon?
steps.content: What is the gravitational force between the Earth and the Moon? The gravitational force between the Earth and the Moon is 1.988 x 1020 N. How did we come to this conclusion? Check out the work below: [16] X Research source Equation: Fgrav = (Gm1m2)/d G = 6.673 x 10 Nm/kg m1 = 5.98 x 1024 kg (the mass of the Earth) m2 = 7.35 x 1022 kg (the mass of the Moon) d = 3.84 x 108 m (the distance between the Earth and the Moon) Plug the variables into the equation. F = 1.988 x 1020 N
